Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Mechanics, Manipulation, and Perception of Deformable Objects for Robotic Manufacturing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The project is motivated by the need of small-to-medium sized businesses in the United States to automate handling and assembly of compliant parts. As a case study, it focuses on robotic installation of a wire harness (a bundle of wires that terminate in electrical connectors). This manufacturing task is ubiquitous but hard to automate because it requires reasoning about deformation of the wire harness. The project is addressing this challenge with new algorithms for manipulation and perception of deformable objects that are based on novel representations of object shape. It considers first the manipulation of a single wire (one piece of a wire harness). It expresses the shape of this wire as the solution to a geometric optimal control problem, and shows that the set of all solutions to this problem is a smooth manifold that can be parameterized by a single coordinate chart. This result leads to an algorithm for manipulation planning that works well and is easy to implement. Objectives include extending this model to consider variable stiffness, plastic deformation, and branching; making manipulation plans robust to perturbation; estimating material properties and shape from sensor data; and experimentally demonstrating robotic installation of a wire harness. Outreach efforts include co-directing a week-long summer institute for high school students, mentoring undergraduate researchers, and organizing an industrial forum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was motivated by the need to automate handling and assembly of compliant parts in manufacturing processes. As a case study, it focused on robotic installation of a wire harness, a bundle of wires that terminate in electrical connectors. This manufacturing task is hard to automate because it requires reasoning about deformation of the wire harness.

 

The project addressed this challenge with new algorithms for manipulation and perception of deformable objects that are based on novel representations of object shape. It considered first the manipulation of a single wire, or one piece of a wire harness. It expressed the shape of this wire as the solution to a geometric optimal control problem, and showed that the set of all solutions to this problem is a smooth manifold that can be parameterized by a single coordinate chart. It further showed that the “free” part of this manifold---i.e., the set of all stable shapes that do not collide with themselves---is path-connected. This result means that, in theory, it is always possible to manipulate a single wire from any stable shape to any other stable shape. The way in which this result was established led to an algorithm for manipulation planning that worked well and was easy to implement.

 

The project also sought to expand access to higher education in engineering to the incarcerated population. Providing higher education to incarcerated men and women has well-established benefits. For example, it results in lower rates of reincarceration and fewer disciplinary incidents within prison. Perhaps more striking is the impact that higher education in prison has for the children of incarcerated men and women. The majority of these men and women are parents. When they are provided higher education in prison, their children---outside of prison---are more likely to attend college. The project developed and taught two undergraduate engineering courses, one on the topic of robotics and the other on the topic of automatic control, to students at the Danville Correctional Center, a medium security adult male state prison in Illinois.
